title: Keep Your Pets Inside
description: It is crucial to keep your pets indoors during the winter, especially when the weather is very cold or windy. Extreme temperatures can lead to hypothermia or frostbite. If you must take your pet outside, ensure they are adequately covered with a coat or sweater and keep the outdoor time very brief. Always make sure their fur coat is completely dry before they venture out.

title: Keep Your Home Warm
description: For pets that usually stay outdoors, it's best to bring them inside during the colder months. Ensure your home is warm enough, especially for older or ailing pets. Consider using a space heater or providing an extra blanket for their bed to maintain their warmth. However, be cautious of small pets like cats that might creep into warm car hoods for shelter; honk your horn or bang on the hood before starting your vehicle.

title: Keep your pets safe from the weather
description: If outdoor time is necessary, protect your pet from the cold wind. Use booties to shield their paws from ice and road salt. Upon returning indoors, diligently clean their paws and legs to remove any dirt or chemical residue. Avoid bathing them immediately before going out and use pet-safe balms or oils to moisturize their paws. Additionally, eliminate any open, stagnant water in your yard to prevent your pets from drinking it, which poses risks of digestive issues or infections like heartworm disease.

title: Make Sure Your Pets Get Enough Water
description: During winter, even if pets are less active, ensuring they drink enough water is vital. Dehydration can be life-threatening. To encourage water intake, consider a pet water fountain or simply ensure their bowl is constantly refilled with water that isn't too cold. Regular indoor playtime or outdoor walks can help stimulate their thirst, ensuring they stay properly hydrated throughout the day.

title: Give Your Pets Plenty of Food
description: Pets often require more food during winter to generate heat and maintain energy levels. Check to make sure you are feeding them sufficient amounts, and you might consider switching to a higher-protein meal if necessary. However, avoid overfeeding them, as the misconception that extra fat keeps them warm is often inaccurate. Monitor your petâ€™s weight closely and ensure they balance their food intake with adequate exercise.

title: Keep Your Pets Active
description: Despite the freezing temperatures, healthy pets still need activity. Keep them active with indoor games like fetch, tug-of-war, or even by setting up a simple obstacle course inside your home. For older pets, gentle joint-stretching exercises may be more suitable than intense activity. Hiding their favourite toys can also encourage them to move around and search, helping them stay engaged and physically fit.
